block.p: LEAD: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 52.
LEAD: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 52.
Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 52.
1. ''We've come too late,'' this man said, in a futile attempt at conciliation. Who is he, to whom was he speaking and what were the circumstances?
2. A private meeting on Capitol Hill spun out of control, stunning some participants. What meeting was it and what happened?
3. Gaylord Perry changed caps each inning while pitching his 300th career victory in 1982, exhibiting baseball's latest craze. What is the craze?
4. Although the 0.7 percent rise in the Consumer Price Index in April was the biggest monthly increase in more than two years, most economists were not alarmed. Why not?
5. The White House is drafting legislation to combat acid rain that would allow companies to buy and sell the right to pollute. What is the reasoning behind this strategy?
6. Researchers are developing a new method for predicting who is vulnerable to cancer and whether a tumor will spread or remain confined to a specific site in the body. What is the method?

7. Members of the Charter Revision Commission struggled to achieve two objectives in the New York City government they are devising, but the goals were usually contradictory. What were they and which one prevailed in the commission's preliminary plan?
8. The Olympian wrath of the Metropolitan Museum of Art has descended upon the Whitney Museum of American Art. What is the reason for this Titanic battle of museums?
9. While China and the Soviet Union renewed normal ties after 30 years of estrangement, the citizens of the two giant neighbors are beginning to envy each other. Why?

10. Although President Bush vowed to ''take back the streets'' from criminals when he unveiled a $1.2 billion crime bill, one part of his program may make that goal difficult to achieve, law-enforcement officials say. What is it?

11. From storefront churches in urban slums to gleaming houses of worship along suburban freeways, a huge cultural transformation is changing the face of religion in the United States. What is happening?
12. Foreign Ministers of the Organization of American States attended an emergency meeting, the first since 1982. What happened at the session?
13. What clue led a scholar in Ashfield, Mass., to conclude that a copy of the Emancipation Proclamation bore the authentic signature of Lincoln?
14. Cito Gaston is expected to have his new baseball job for only a short time, but his appointment received special notice. Explain.
